turns.content: Missing someone you have feelings for, even if the relationship didn't work out, is normal. It's understandable to feel sad when you think about someone who was important to you. Grieving the end of the relationship and allowing yourself to feel those emotions is a necessary step in the healing process. It may take time, but eventually, the pain will fade and you will be able to move on and find happiness in the future.
How do I know whether to reach out to him and rekindle the relationship or not?
Every time we rekindle the relationship, we end up fighting and it falls apart. Should I maybe give it 6 months or a year before I reach out to him again?

It is ultimately up to you to decide whether to reach out to your former partner or not. However, if you both keep repeating the pattern of rekindling the relationship and then fighting, it may be beneficial to take some time apart to reflect and work on personal growth before considering a reconciliation. A 6-month or a year break can give you both time to gain clarity and see if there are any underlying issues that need to be addressed.
Would a few months be enough for a break, or should I wait longer?

The appropriate time for a break in the relationship depends on the individuals involved and the reasons for the break. It's recommended that you take the time you need to reflect on the relationship, process your emotions, and determine what you truly want in a partner. This could mean waiting a few months or longer, but ultimately, the decision is up to you. Consider seeking the guidance of a therapist or counselor to help you make the best decision for yourself.
Should I drop off his belongings at his place? I don’t want to be knocking on the door, texting him, or trying to contact him/rekindle our relationship.

Dropping off his belongings at his place could be a reasonable solution, as long as you ensure it is done in a safe and socially distant manner. It allows you to return his belongings without having to directly communicate with him, which could reduce the risk of rekindling the relationship or causing further conflicts. If you feel that it would be too difficult to do so in person, consider sending them to him through a delivery service.
How can I process what happened during our relationship and focus on self-care?

You can focus on self-care by:

1. Practicing self-reflection and introspection, try to understand what you learned from the relationship.
2. Engaging in activities that you enjoy and that make you feel good, such as exercise, hobbies, or spending time with friends.
3. Talking to a trusted friend or therapist, this can help you process the relationship and any emotions you are feeling.
4. Taking time for yourself and focusing on your needs.
5. Avoiding contact with your ex for now

Where could his trust issues have stemmed from? His past relationships?

Trust issues can stem from many sources, including past experiences and relationships, childhood experiences, trauma, or attachment styles. It's possible that his past relationships could have contributed to his trust issues, but it's also possible that there are other underlying factors. Without more information, it's difficult to determine the specific cause of his trust issues.
Why was he so adamant on being the only person I had sex with if he didn’t trust me or want to be with me?

It is not possible to determine the specific motivations and thought processes of another person without their direct input. The individual's reasoning and feelings could have been complex and influenced by multiple factors, such as past experiences, personal beliefs and insecurities, relationship dynamics, and more. It may be helpful to reflect on your own feelings and needs in the relationship, and consider seeking support from friends, family, or a therapist to work through your emotions and move forward.
Why did he always criticize me for wearing revealing clothing in the gym, even though I asked him multiple times to come with me and he never wanted to?

It's possible that he was uncomfortable with your gym attire because it made him feel insecure about his own body or because he wanted to protect you from unwanted attention from others. Alternatively, he may have been trying to control your behavior and clothing choices in order to maintain his own power dynamic in the relationship. Without more context, it's impossible to say for certain.
Could him criticizing my gym attire be connected to him constantly accusing me of wanting to be with other men?

It's possible that the criticism of your gym attire is connected to his accusations of you wanting to be with other men. Jealousy and insecurity can sometimes manifest as controlling behavior, such as trying to dictate how someone else dresses. However, it's also possible that his behavior was driven by different factors and motivations, and it's difficult to know for sure without hearing his perspective.

Why did he project his insecurities onto me by criticizing my gym clothes and accusing me of cheating all the time? Couldn’t he have opened up to me about it or expressed those feelings in a healthier way?

It's possible that he projected his own insecurities and anxieties onto you, as a way of coping with his own feelings of jealousy or fear of losing you. Instead of communicating his feelings to you, he expressed them through criticism and accusations. Communication and expression of feelings in a healthy way can help to address such issues in a relationship. It is important for both partners to have open and honest communication to build trust and resolve conflicts.
Was it okay for him to try and control what I wear to the gym or soccer? Or criticize me for wearing those clothes, even though they made me feel confident and happy in my body?

No, it is not okay for someone to control what another person wears or to criticize them for their clothing choices. Clothing choices are a personal matter, and each person has the right to wear what makes them feel comfortable and confident. Criticizing someone's appearance is also not a healthy way to express emotions or insecurities. Everyone has the right to make their own choices without fear of criticism or control.
Was it okay for him to criticize me and slut shame me for what I wore in the gym or when I played soccer around other men?

No, it was not okay for him to criticize you or shame you for what you wear. Everyone has the right to choose their own clothing and express themselves through their appearance without fear of judgment or criticism. Clothing choices do not determine a person's worth, intentions, or behavior. You deserve to be treated with respect and kindness regardless of what you wear.

Why did he demand nude photos, criticize my gym attire, and slut shame me for being in the gym or playing soccer with other men if he knew he didn’t want to be with me long term? If he didn’t want me to be his girlfriend, then what did it matter? Could this have been connected to his past two relationships?

It's possible that his past experiences and insecurities may have played a role in his possessiveness and controlling behavior towards you. However, demanding nude photos, criticizing your appearance, and shame you is not okay or acceptable behavior. This could be a sign of toxic and abusive dynamics in the relationship. Relationships should be based on mutual respect, trust, and healthy communication, rather than control and manipulation.
How could his past relationships have led to criticizing my gym clothes and playing soccer with other men? It seems like a really unusual way to try and establish control over me

Past experiences and relationships can greatly influence an individual's behavior and perspective in future relationships. If the previous relationships had experiences of infidelity or trust issues, this could make the individual more insecure and prone to possessiveness and jealousy in future relationships. This could then manifest as an attempt to control or criticize their partner's actions, including their gym attire and activities with others. However, it is not a justification for such behavior and it is important for individuals to work on their own insecurities and communicate effectively in their relationships.
Why would he be afraid of losing me if he broke up with me and kicked me out of his place multiple times?

Insecurity and fear of loss often stem from a deep-seated fear of abandonment or rejection. It's possible that despite ending the relationship and forcing you out, he still felt a strong emotional connection to you and was afraid of completely losing you. This fear could have caused him to try and exert control in various ways, including criticizing your appearance or accusing you of cheating, as a way of trying to keep you close. However, these behaviors are not healthy or acceptable in any relationship.
But wouldn’t him accusing me of cheating and criticizing my gym clothes be him pushing me away? How would it make him feel closer to me or like he could trust me more?

People often act in ways that are not aligned with their emotions and desires, and these behaviors can be driven by insecurities and past experiences. Accusing a partner of cheating and criticizing their clothing choices could be a way for him to express his insecurities, establish control, or avoid vulnerability in the relationship. This type of behavior can push a partner away and damage trust, rather than bring them closer.
